cards.back:
x(t) = a₀ + Σ_{k=1}^{∞} [a_k cos(kω₀t) + b_k sin(kω₀t)]

where a₀ = X₀, a_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)cos(kω₀t)dt, b_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)sin(kω₀t)dt

cards.front: How do a_k and b_k relate to X_k for real signals?
cards.back:
a_k = 2Re(X_k)
b_k = −2Im(X_k)

This comes from a_k = X_k + X_{−k} and b_k = j(X_k − X_{−k}) with X_{−k} = X_k*.

cards.front: State the orthogonality condition for FS basis functions.
cards.back:
⟨φ_k, φ_m⟩ = (1/T₀)∫_{T₀} e^{jkω₀t} · e^{−jmω₀t} dt = δ_{km}

= 1 if k = m
= 0 if k ≠ m

This is the Kronecker delta — basis functions are orthonormal.

cards.front: Why do harmonics with k ≠ m integrate to zero over one period?
cards.back: e^{j(k−m)ω₀t} completes an integer number of full cycles over T₀ (since k−m is an integer). The integral of a sinusoid over complete cycles is always zero.

cards.front: What is the physical analogy for orthogonality of FS basis functions?
cards.back: It's like orthogonal axes (x̂, ŷ, ẑ) in 3D. Projecting a vector onto one axis gives the component along that axis without contamination from other axes. Similarly, projecting x(t) onto e^{jkω₀t} gives X_k with no cross-talk from other harmonics.

cards.front: What factor distinguishes the trig FS coefficient formulas from the EFS?
cards.back:
Factor of 2:
a_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)cos(kω₀t)dt
b_k = (2/T₀)∫x(t)sin(kω₀t)dt

vs EFS: X_k = (1/T₀)∫x(t)e^{−jkω₀t}dt

cards.front: Why is the EFS preferred over trig FS in engineering?
cards.back: EFS provides compact complex representation: X_k = |X_k|e^{j∠X_k} directly gives magnitude and phase. Properties (shift, differentiation, etc.) are cleaner. Trig FS splits into two real coefficients a_k and b_k, losing compactness.

cards.front: What range does k take in the trig FS sum?
cards.back:
k = 1 to ∞ (plus a separate a₀ term for DC).

Contrast with EFS: k = −∞ to +∞. In trig FS, the +k and −k pairs are combined into single cos/sin terms.
